Title.evidence: A Randomised Controlled Trial Comparing Patient-Specific Instrumentation with Conventional Techniques in Unicompartmental Knee Arthroplasty

Trial_Design.evidence: Participants were randomised to receive either PSI or conventional instrumentation.

Participants.evidence: 60 patients, aged 54–72 years, with a mean BMI of 28 kg/m², undergoing UKA.

Intervention.evidence: Participants were randomised to receive either PSI or conventional instrumentation.

Objective.evidence: This study investigates whether patient-specific instrumentation (PSI) offers superior results compared to conventional methods.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was gait parameters, assessed using three-dimensional analysis at 1 year post-surgery.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was conducted using a computer-generated sequence, with allocation concealment ensured.

Blinding.evidence: Outcome assessors were blinded to the intervention.

Number_Randomised.evidence: This randomised controlled trial included 60 patients.

Result_Outcome.evidence: At 1 year, no significant differences were found in gait parameters between the PSI and conventional groups: double limb support (31% vs. 30%; p = 0.67) and walking speed (1.59 m/s vs. 1.57 m/s; p = 0.41).

Harms.evidence: No adverse events were reported in either group.
